job_title: SAP Team Manager in Jerusalem, Jerusalem

pros: stable job in jerusalem for a working mom

review_title: Great people great benefits great work!

review_title: The Gold Standard for Jewish Nonprofit
pros: Excellent team, very professional environment, meaningful mission, very good benefits package

pros: The people are amazing and the work is very meaningful
cons: Sometimes a bit disorganized but overall loved working there

pros: Great work-life balance, versatile projects

pros: Work culture, meaningful work, great people
cons: none that I can think of

pros: Benefits are fantastic, the people are kind and committed, the work can be quite interesting depending on your role. JDC likes to say its employees are one big family. Depending on who you work for and what connections you have, you could be treated as an invaluable employee.
cons: Depending on who you work for, you could be stuck in the same role for far too long, with no opportunity for growth. There is either too much turnover or people stay there stagnant for decades. Departments are in their own silos. Extremely bureaucratic. An almost corporate non-profit but not as professional as it thinks it is.

review_title: Appears to value diversity but doesn't strive to be inclusive in reality
pros:
- Great benefits and days off

- Generous office space — snacks in pantry, bagel Fridays, ice cream socials during the summer,  sit/standing desks, occasional fun events

- *Some* roles provide great work life balance, you can come in and leave on time.
cons:
- The company appears to value diversity but doesn't strive to be inclusive in reality

- HR department is led by incompetent leaders, ignorant of low morale in the office, and poor at managing crises

- Employees have been transparent and expressive about their concerns but Senior Management have yet to make any improvements. 

- Certain bad behavior in the office often goes unpunished depending on who you are

- I've observed that some POC/non-Jewish employees are not valued/recognized for their contribution, often excluded from key planning/decision-making processes,  and lack career opportunities

- Dysfunctional processes and bureaucracy makes it challenging to get work done

pros: The cause is amazing and if you are working outside the offices, you get to see the great support jdc does. Great benefits.
cons: If you are working in the offices, it is very political and bureaucratic. Depending on the department you work in, employees are not heard and management has no idea what they are doing. Had a manager tell me I’m working for a paycheck and that’s all the acknowledgment I can get. HR doesn’t find solutions and find a way to sweep things under the rug instead of working with the department. People here are overworked and constantly dealing with rude management. Really sad to see.

job_title: Global Jewish Service Corps in New York, NY
pros: Got to travel to many parts of the world. Learned new languages. Did creative programming with people of all ages. Field staff is incredible and organization makes a big difference in the lives of many poor.
cons: The organization is very bureaucratic. The New York office, where the supervisors are located, does not give much guidance or help.

pros: The staff is lovely. Family oriented, great benefits, work life balance
cons: Resistant to change, no opportunities for advancement or development. Poor Management

review_title: My experience at JDC although shorter than I would have initially preferred, was enjoyable and a learning experience
pros: Young, energetic, making a difference
cons: No path for upward mobility, bureaucratic

review_title: JDC: Mission driven and supportive of growth
pros: JDC has been an incredible place to grow and develop as a young professional. I've been given many growth opportunities and have identified incredible mentors. It is a truly mission-driven organization and is guided by values of mutual responsibility and repair for the world.
cons: The work can require long hours and travel over weekends, but the organization is so compelling that it makes it worth it.

review_title: Great Mission and Smart Mission Driven Professionals
pros: My experience has been one in which i was invested in, supported in my career growth, pushed to perform at very high standards and have been inspired by the caliber of my colleagues from day one
cons: Over the years, we have gotten more bureaucratic but i find that that also means that there has been more oversight of finances and consistency in how people are treated.

pros:
Excellent benefits and PTO/holidays. 
Some great colleagues
Fantastic and meaningful mission
cons: The N.Y. office is an unnecessary waste of donations. Management there is terrible and needs significant training. They are very disconnected from the day to day work.

review_title: Awesome fellowships abroad, working with great communities.
job_title: Global Service Fellow in Addis Ababa
pros: Great way to live in another country and do meaningful work. Most of the fellowships are with Jewish communities, but not all. The JDC takes good care of you financially.
cons: It can be challenging to work in the field, but this should be something you anticipate and are excited about.

review_title: Fellowship Position - an opportunity I couldn't get anywhere else.
pros: Meaningful work -- the projects are worthwhile and the impact immense. Employees don't end up at American JDC by accident, they come with purpose.
cons: As most large organizations, structure is complex and bureaucracy moves slowly -- communicating often and pushing agendas are key.

pros: Warm and engaging people, practically zero pressure.  Work outside of normal hours is rare.  Excellent compensation package, lots of off time.
cons: Many tasks handled by office in Israel (even though NYC is HQ for the organization).

review_title: Great place to work in - and a great opportunity
pros: Great position to influence large scale projects and help social entrepreneurs tap into a lot of resources
cons: bureaucratic and big, it’s sometimes hard to navigate the politics between the two big partner organizations.

pros: Immersive experience, gaining on the ground grassroots insight into communities dealing with a plethora of development challenges. Supportive and knowledgeable staff at headquarters and on the ground.
cons: Challenges managing bureaucracy when dealing with the headquarters in NYC

pros:

cons:

pros: good workplace atmosphere, great colleagues

bureaucratic, not very innovative
